result.markdown: --- title: "Hands on Exercise 4 Part 2: Visual Statistical Analysis" author: "Liaw Ying Ting, Celin" date: 7 May 2025 date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true warning: false freeze: true --- # 6.1 Learning Outcome Gain hands on experience using: - ggstatsplot: to create visual graphics with rich statistical information - performance package to visualise model diagnostics - parameters package to visualise model parameters # 6.2 Visual Statistical Analysis with ggstatsplot [**ggstatsplot**]{.underline} is an extension of ggplot 2 package for creating graphics with details from statistical tests # 6.3 Getting Started ## 6.3.1 Installing and Launching R Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(tidyverse, ggstatsplot) ``` ::: ## 6.3.2 Importing Data Importing Exam.csv data using tidyverse packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam <- read_csv("Exam_data.csv") ``` ::: ## 6.3.3 One-sample test: gghistostats() method In the code chunk below, gghistostats() is used to build an visual of one-sample test on English scores. ::: panel-tabset ### The Plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04_Part2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### The Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1234) gghistostats( data = exam, x = ENGLISH, type = "bayes", test.value = 60, xlab = "English scores" ) ``` ::: ::: **Explanation of the Results:** Ho: The mean english score is 60 H1: The mean english score is not equals to 60 - **log₁₀(BF₀₁) = -31.45**\ This is the logarithm of the Bayes Factor **in favor of the alternative hypothesis** over the null: This is **extreme evidence** in favor of the **alternative hypothesis**. - **posterior difference = 7.16**\ The estimated mean difference between the observed group and a comparison value (likely a hypothesized mean like 0 or 50), with the observed average English score being significantly higher. - **CI⁹⁵% \[5.54, 8.75\] (ETI)**\ This is the **95% credible interval** (Equal-Tail Interval), suggesting that the true mean difference is very likely between 5.54 and 8.75. - **JZS Cauchy = 0.71**\ This is the **scale parameter** for the Cauchy prior distribution used in the Bayesian t-test (Jeffreys–Zellner–Siow prior), controlling the expected effect size. - **Dashed Blue Line (x = 74.74)**\ This shows the **sample mean** of the English scores. The peak at this point suggests most scores cluster around here. ## 6.3.4 Unpacking the Bayes Factor - Bayes Factor is the ratio of the likelihood of one particular hypothesis to the likelihood of another. It is a measure of strength of evidence in favor of one theory among 2 competing theories - It gives us a way to evaluate the data in favor of a null hypothesis based on external information and tells us the weight of evidence is in favor of the hypothesis - Bayes factor is often written as B10 and can be defined mathematically as" ![](images/clipboard-4142434025.png) - The [Schwarz criterion](https://www.statisticshowto.com/bayesian-information-criterion/) is one of the easiest ways to calculate rough approximation of the Bayes Factor ## 6.3.5 How to interpret Bayes Factor It can be any positive number and can be interpreted in the table below: ![](images/clipboard-116261035.png) ## 6.3.6 Two-sample mean test: ggbetweenstats() The code ggbetweenstats() is used to build a visual for two-sample mean test of Math scores by gender. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggbetweenstats( data = exam, x = GENDER, y = MATHS, type = "np", messages = FALSE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04_Part2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Summary of results from plot:** - **Test used:** `W_Mann–Whitney = 13011.00`\ This is a non-parametric alternative to the t-test (used when data may not be normally distributed). - **p-value = 0.91**\ ➤ This is **not statistically significant**. A high p-value (much greater than 0.05) suggests **no evidence** to reject the null hypothesis.\ In other words, **there is no significant difference in Maths scores between males and females**. - **Median (Female) = 74**, **Median (Male) = 75**\ ➤ Scores are nearly identical in central tendency. - **Rank biserial correlation = 0.007**\ ➤ This is a **very small effect size**, indicating negligible practical difference. - **95% CI = \[−0.12, 0.13\]**\ ➤ The confidence interval for the effect size includes 0, further confirming that **there's no meaningful difference** - **n = 322**\ ➤ Total number of observations (170 females, 152 males). ## 6.3.7 Oneway ANOVA Test: ggbetweenstats() method The code ggbetweenstats() is used to build a visual for one-way ANOVA test on English score by race. - "ns" - only non-significant - "s" - only significant - "all" - everything ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggbetweenstats( data = exam, x = RACE, y = ENGLISH, type = "p", mean.ci = TRUE, pairwise.comparisons = TRUE, pairwise.display = "s", p.adjust.method = "fdr", messages = FALSE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04_Part2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Summary of results from plot:** - **Welch’s ANOVA**: F(3,23.8)=10.15,p=1.71×10−4F(3, 23.8) = 10.15,\quad p = 1.71 \times 10^{-4}F(3,23.8)=10.15,p=1.71×10−4 ➤ The **p-value is very small**, indicating a **statistically significant difference** in English scores among the racial groups. - **Effect size (ω²) = 0.50**\ ➤ This is a **very large effect**, suggesting race explains a substantial proportion of variance in English scores. - **CI₉₅% \[0.21, 1.00\]** for ω²\ ➤ Confirms the effect size is meaningful. - **n = 322**\ ➤ Sample size (with group sizes shown under each violin). - **p (FDR-adjusted) = 5.19e-06**\ ➤ Adjusted p-value from Games–Howell pairwise comparisons — confirms at least one pairwise difference is significant. ### 6.3.7.1 ggbetweenstats - Summary of tests Following (between-subjects) tests are carried out for each type of analyses ![](images/clipboard-3963458938.png) ![![](images/clipboard-142720698.png)](images/clipboard-1013962986.png) ## 6.3.8 Significant Test of Correlation: ggscatterstats() In the code chunk below, [ggscatterstats()](https://indrajeetpatil.github.io/ggstatsplot/reference/ggscatterstats.html) is used to build a visual for Significant Test of Correlation between Maths scores and English scores. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggscatterstats( data = exam, x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH, marginal = FALSE, ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04_Part2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Summary of results from plot:** - **Pearson correlation** ​=0.83:\ ➤ This indicates a **very strong positive correlation** — students who score well in Maths tend to also score well in English. - **p-value = 1.70e-83**\ ➤ This is an extremely small p-value, so the correlation is **highly statistically significant**. - **95% CI for** r: \[0.79, 0.86\]\ ➤ The confidence interval confirms the correlation is both strong and precise. - **t(320) = 26.72**\ ➤ The test statistic for evaluating correlation; much larger than typical critical values. - **n = 322 pairs**\ ➤ Total number of students with both scores available. ## 6.3.9 Significant Test of Association (Dependence): ggbarstats() methods In the code chunk below, the Maths scores is binned into a 4-class variable by using [cut()](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/cut). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam1 <- exam %>% mutate(MATHS_bins = cut(MATHS, breaks = c(0,60,75,85,100)) ) ``` ::: In this code chunk below [ggbarstats](https://indrajeetpatil.github.io/ggstatsplot/reference/ggbarstats.html) is used to build a visual for Significant Test of Association. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggbarstats(exam1, x = MATHS_bins, y = GENDER) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04_Part2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Summary of results from plot:** - **Chi-squared test** χPearson2(3)=1.04, p=0.79\chi^2_{\text{Pearson}}(3) = 1.04,\ p = 0.79χPearson2​(3)=1.04, p=0.79\ ➤ **Not statistically significant**, meaning there's **no evidence** of an association between gender and Maths score bins. - **Cramér's V = 0.00**, with **95% CI \[0.00, 0.08\]**\ ➤ **Effect size is negligible**. There is no practical difference between the two gender groups in how their Maths scores are distributed. - **Sample size** n=322n = 322n=322:\ 170 females and 152 males
